review_title: My 20 Year Experience Working at American Public University System
job_title: Vice President in Charles Town, WV
pros: I have been with American Public University System for over 20 years and in during my tenure, I have witnessed remarkable growth in our drive to be America's premier digital university. The people I work with are phenomenal. We place students-first in everything that we do. Being student-centric ensures our primary focus is on the needs and growth of our students. By prioritizing student well-being, personalized learning experiences, and support systems, we foster a positive environment, enhance academic success, and prepare students for real-world challenges, contributing their long-term success. We also focus on collegiality, which cultivates a supportive and collaborative atmosphere among our faculty, staff, and students. We encourage respectful communication, teamwork, and sharing of knowledge, which fosters a sense of belonging, encourages interdisciplinary approaches, and promotes a vibrant intellectual community, which all contributes to our institutional excellence. Finally, everything that we do at American Public University System revolves around trust and teamwork, which are essential in a university setting. Trust and teamwork enable effective collaboration and innovation. The professional atmosphere at American Public University System allows us to openly share ideas, take risks, and work towards common goals. Being a member of a university that is student-centric and collegial, which places an emphasis on trust and teamwork all of which helps foster a positive work environment, allows us to tackle complex challenges more effectively, ultimately leading to growth and success of our students, faculty, staff, and alumni. One only need attend our annual graduation and commencement in Washington, DC, to fully appreciate the life-changing and positive impact we have on our students. I am PROUD to be a member of such a wonderful institution!
cons: Because we are a digital university, with students and faculty spread throughout the United States and abroad, we generally only get to physically meet our students during graduation and commencement.

review_title: You Might Make More at McDonald's
job_title: Professor in Charlestown, IN
pros: Work from home flexibility is about all.
cons:
I'm a FT faculty member in the School of Security and Global Studies. I teach 6 classes every month, which comes out to roughly 130 students, or 22 learners per class. I also manage 5 classes and must regularly update them. So you may be wondering what this workload translates to in human terms?

The answer is 10 -12 hour days 6 days a week. On the 7th day, it's more like 4 hours. When you break down the hours worked with my compensation, which is less than 70k, my hourly pay is around $10.00 an hour. I can honestly tell you my daughter makes more working the drive through at MCD than I do, when you break it down hourly. 

Even doing a crappy job with minimum interactions/feedback, my reality is 12 hour days, 6 days a week and Sundays 4. How could it not be with such outrageously high teaching loads? I've already got a heart stint and am not interested in another. This will be my last year teaching here. My doctor is pretty much requiring it.

review_title: Working As Full-Time Faculty At American Public University Sucks!
job_title: Full Time Faculty in Milwaukee, WI
pros: They match your 401k. Honestly, that's all I can think of because the rest is atrocious .
cons:
After nearly a 5 years of employment as fulltime faculty, I finally quit. I couldn't handle teaching 6 classes a month with 100 plus students month after month for 11 months out of the year.

It is bad enough we have to teach those kinds of numbers but it doesn't stop there. They also make you build new classes EVERY month that roll out the next month. Imagine grading 100 graduate level writing assignments PER WEEK (and marking them up comments) every week.  Do the math. With 125 students (average), that's 125 papers you grade per week or 500 papers per month! Now throw in discussion assignments you also must grade each week. That's another 500 (or more) you grade per month.

But wait ... there's more. 

Fulltime faculty also are forced to be course managers for up to 5 classes. This means monthly tweaks and technical updates that you are REQUIRED to attend to. And because they jettisoned textbooks to save money, they rely on faculty to scour the web for free reading material.  Would you go to a school for a masters degree and not have a textbook in ANY of your courses? I'm not kidding, this is exactly what APUS does through it's "open resource" "initiative. 

And did I mention they required you to respond to 50 % over all posts in a substantive way? That may not sound bad but when you teach 125 students a month, we're talking 62 posts a week. This doesn't include having to reply to 100% of the introductions in week 1.

Now throw in student emails (average 10 per day) and the technical tweaks ... plus required faculty meetings, and you are literally working 12 hour days, 7 days a week. You don't dare take a day away from the classrooms because if you do you'll never catch up. And omg NEVER get sick. Nobody will cover your classrooms.

Did you know faculty who have worked there 15 years get the same vacation time as 1 year? Oh, and did ya know the "1 month" vacay is really just 2 weeks because you are building classes during your time off?

review_title: Slave labor with very bad leadership
job_title: Faculty in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The positive things that once applied no longer do.
cons:
I've been at APUS for 10 years. It used to be an innovative, fun environment where you wanted to teach. Over the past 5 years, that's gone.

Since January, I've been teaching over 100 students month after month after month. Harsh teaching requirements that require 12-15 hour days almost everyday. I'm a mom with a small child at home. I'm so busy that I don't even have time to be with her. 

Last year I was unfortunate enough to have contracted the flu. When I called my program director to advise I was being admitted to the hospital with pneumonia, she literally said to me "You can still teach because most hospitals have Internet. Do you have a laptop?" 

Speaking of program managers...

I've had 3 of them in the past five  years because they all eventually quit.  It's a good old boys club mentality. Look at senior management. How many are people of color? Maybe one?

I know others here have complained about the pay for faculty. I agree but also need to say things have reached a point that money alone won't fix . We're overworked to the point that is slave labor. 

There has been some talk outside of the faculty lounge of a union. I sure hope that happens. I'd vote yes in a heartbeat.
